__data__.text:
Barcelona, the largest city in Catalonia, is situated in the Spanish Levant on the Mediterranean coast, between 41°16' and 41°30' north latitude and 1°54' and 2°18' east longitude. The city spans 102.16 km², with a plain area of 11 km long and 6 km wide, surrounded by the sea, the Collserola mountain range, and the deltas of the Besós and Llobregat rivers. Barcelona has a Mediterranean climate with mild winters and low rainfall, averaging 600 mm per year.

The city's terrain is hilly and undulating, formed by a substrate of slate, granitic formations, clays, and limestones. Barcelona was once covered in torrents and streams, but now almost the entire surface area is urbanized. The city is the second most populous in Spain, with 1,604,555 inhabitants in 2015, and is the cultural, political, and economic hub of Catalonia. Barcelona is home to the autonomous government, the Parliament of Catalonia, the provincial deputation, the archbishopric, the IV Military Region, a port, an airport, and a comprehensive network of railroads and roads.

Administratively, Barcelona is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods, including the old core of the city, the one derived from the Roman and medieval periods, plus the Barceloneta neighborhood, created in the eighteenth century. This area received significant immigration from the rest of Spain during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and has continued to do so in the twenty-first century, although with immigrants from other countries. This district has the oldest and lowest socioeconomic level population in the city, although a slow process of gentrification has begun in parallel to the urban development plans carried out in the district.

Barcelona is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods, each with its own unique history and characteristics. Ciutat Vella, the oldest part of the city, has numerous monuments, low socioeconomic level population, and is an important tourist attraction. Eixample, formed after the demolition of the city walls, is densely populated and has many modernist architectural works. Sants-Montjuïc, the largest district, has low population density, high percentage of green area, and includes the Montjuïc mountain. Les Corts, originally an agricultural area, has a high rate of young people and is home to many financial institutions. Sarrià-Sant Gervasi, one of the largest districts, is a high status residential area with a predominance of single-family houses. Gràcia, with narrow streets and tightly packed houses, has a high percentage of elderly people and low-middle class population. Horta-Guinardó, originally an agricultural area and summer residences, has low population density and a predominance of young and lower-middle class population.

Horta-Guinardó, one of the largest districts, was originally an agricultural area and summer residences that later received numerous immigrants, primarily in the first two thirds of the 20th century. It has low population density and a predominantly young, lower-middle class population. Nou Barris is the most recently created district, with a majority immigrant population and a history of real estate speculation, shanty towns, and self-construction. The population is primarily working class with low purchasing power. Sant Andreu, originally a municipality, was an agricultural and milling area that became industrialized in the mid-19th century and experienced a wave of immigration in the mid-20th century. It has undergone revitalization through commercial activities and the arrival of the high-speed train. Sant Martí, also originally an agricultural and milling area, experienced deindustrialization and a shift towards new technology-based economic activities. It welcomed a large immigrant population and underwent renovation for the 1992 Olympic Games. The administrative division of Barcelona has evolved over time, with the city initially divided into four quarters in 1389, which later increased to five quarters in the 18th century, and underwent numerous divisions in the 19th century for political reasons.

In the 15th century, Raval was added as a new quarter, and the city was divided into five quarters in the 18th century, which were subdivided into eight neighborhoods each. Numerous political-motivated divisions occurred in the 19th century, leading to 10 districts. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, neighboring municipalities were incorporated, and the city was reorganized into 10 districts. In 1933, two more districts were added, and in 1984, the current division into ten districts was established, seeking to preserve historical and morphological identity while ensuring functional delimitation and decentralization. The last reform in 2006 focused on establishing 73 neighborhoods, causing controversy due to fragmentation of some historical neighborhoods and unmet aspirations of some neighborhood units. Barcelona's history dates back to its founding as Barcino by Roman colonizers in the first century BC.

In 2006, Barcelona was reorganized into 73 neighborhoods, aiming to preserve historical and cultural identity while ensuring functional delimitation and decentralization. This decision faced controversy due to the fragmentation of historical neighborhoods, such as El Clot, Sants, Esquerra de l'Eixample, and Poblenou, which were divided into smaller units. Additionally, some neighborhood units had unmet aspirations, like Can Caralleu, Penitents, Torre Melina, and El Polvorí.

Barcelona's history dates back to its founding as Barcino by the Roman colonizers in the first century BC. The Romans built a small walled city with an orthogonal layout, centered on the forum, and provided basic services and infrastructure. The city was enclosed by a wall with 74 towers, which was reinforced in the 4th century due to external threats. After the fall of the Roman Empire, the city underwent various conquests and experienced periods of integration into different empires, retaining its urban structure and evolving into a military stronghold. During the Middle Ages, Barcelona became a county, then part of the Crown of Aragon, and the political and economic center of the Principality of Catalonia, developing into a significant maritime and commercial hub in the Mediterranean Sea.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona was rebuilt after its destruction in 985 and developed into a significant political, religious, and commercial center. It was constituent as a county and later became part of the Crown of Aragon, serving as the economic and political hub of the Principality of Catalonia and a major maritime and commercial force in the Mediterranean Sea. The city's urban structure, originating from Roman times, remained relatively unchanged and was used as a military stronghold, leading to its dominance over neighboring cities. Suburbanization began, and the city expanded with the creation of new neighborhoods outside the city walls, such as the Raval district and the neighborhoods around churches and monasteries. These developments led to the establishment of the Council of One Hundred in 1265 to manage the city's administration, including food supply, infrastructure maintenance, population census, and urban planning. The agricultural plain surrounding Barcelona supplied the city with fruits, vegetables, and wine. In the 10th century, canals were constructed to direct the waters of the Llobregat and Besòs rivers to the city's vicinity. The Jewish quarter, the Call, existed from 692 until its destruction in 1391, and was located between the current streets of Ferran, Banys Nous, Palla, and Bisbe.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona underwent significant development and became a major political, religious, and commercial hub. The city was rebuilt after its destruction in 985 and expanded with new neighborhoods, such as the Raval district, leading to the construction of a new wall in 1260. The Raval neighborhood was initially a suburb with orchards and religious buildings. The city's urban fabric consisted of different areas of influence, including aristocracy, institutional power, religious orders, guilds, and trade associations. Houses were typically "artisan type," while larger buildings were churches, palaces, or institutional buildings.

In the 14th and 15th centuries, the city extended its walled enclosure with the Raval wall, covering an area of 218 ha. This extension led to the creation of La Rambla, initially occupied by religious institutions and later urbanized, becoming one of the city's most emblematic places. Additionally, an extensive network of roads emerged in the plain of Barcelona, connecting the city with various suburbs, villages, and points of interest.

During the Middle Ages, Barcelona experienced significant development and became a major hub for politics, religion, and commerce. The city was rebuilt after its destruction in 985, leading to the construction of new neighborhoods and a new wall in 1260. The Raval neighborhood, initially a suburb with orchards and religious buildings, was urbanized and extended the city's walled enclosure in the 14th and 15th centuries. This expansion led to the creation of La Rambla and an extensive network of roads connecting the city to suburbs, villages, and points of interest.

In the Early Modern Age, Barcelona and Catalonia became part of the Hispanic Monarchy. The city was confined within its walls, with the only expansion occurring in the neighborhood of La Barceloneta. The main urban reforms during this period included the construction of the sea wall, the Plaça de la Seu in front of the cathedral's main portal, and the Plaça de San Iu. An artificial port was also built to meet the needs of Barcelona's important mercantile center.

In the 17th century, the city wall was extended again with the construction of five new gates, and streets were paved, sewers were installed, and drinking water fountains were built. However, with the victory of Philip V in the War of Succession, much of Catalonia's and Barcelona's autonomy was truncated, and the municipal jurisdiction was reduced to the city, losing its metropolitan area influence.

During the 18th century, Barcelona underwent significant urban development, including paved streets, installed sewers, and built drinking water fountains. The city's autonomy was truncated after the War of Succession, with the Nueva Planta Decree eliminating the Generalitat, the Corts, and the Consell de Cent, replacing them with a military government. The municipal jurisdiction was reduced to the city, causing a loss of influence in the metropolitan area. However, the population increased notably, and the economy became industrialized, leading to the Industrial Revolution.

The Bourbons initiated military engineering works, such as the castle of Montjuïc and the fortress of the Citadel, which required the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, leaving 4500 people homeless. Two new military roads were constructed, the Mataró road and the Creu Coberta road.

In 1753, the construction of the neighborhood of La Barceloneta began, designed by the engineer Pedro Martín Cermeño, with a grid of orthogonal streets and blocks of houses of elongated plan, showcasing academic baroque urbanism. The Edicto de obreria was approved in 1771, a municipal ordinance aimed at controlling private works in the city, establishing the obligation to request a building permit, accompanied by a report and the payment of fees.

The redevelopment of La Rambla was carried out between 1776 and 1778, and the Born and Boqueria markets were established as the only two general supply markets. The 19th century saw a great economic revitalization, primarily linked to the textile industry, leading to a Catalan cultural renaissance.

During the 18th century, Barcelona experienced urban development with paved streets, installed sewers, and built drinking water fountains. The city's autonomy was reduced, but the population increased, and the economy became industrialized, leading to the Industrial Revolution. The Bourbons initiated military engineering works, causing the demolition of houses and homelessness. The neighborhood of La Barceloneta was constructed, and the Edicto de obreria was approved to control private works. The Born and Boqueria markets were established, and aspects such as weights and measures were regulated. In the 19th century, the city walls were demolished, allowing expansion under the Eixample project. The Citadel was also demolished and transformed into a public park. The population grew, and the textile and metallurgical industries became essential. Industrialization brought about changes in urban planning, with new needs of the economic sectors requiring a strong concentration of labor and auxiliary services. The municipal ordinances were consolidated, and new ones were drawn up to take into account the new specificities of the expansion. Important urban planning actions included the opening of Calle de Fernando and the expansion of the Pla de Palau.

In the 18th and 19th centuries, Barcelona underwent urban development, including paved streets, installed sewers, and built drinking water fountains. The city's autonomy was reduced, but the population and economy grew, leading to the Industrial Revolution. The Eixample project caused old ordinances to become obsolete, and new ones were established, increasing the area of plot occupation from 50% to 70%. Notable urban planning actions included the opening of Calle de Fernando, the expansion of the Pla de Palau, and the creation of new public spaces from former parish cemeteries. The gas lighting was introduced in 1842, and the first railroad line in peninsular Spain was established in 1848, connecting Barcelona with Mataró. The city became the center of a railway network, and fire and police services appeared.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona's urban development continued with the creation of the railway network in the shape of a "Catalan eight," intersecting at the city, and the establishment of the first fire and police services. The city's first fire department, Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona, was created in 1865, led by architect Antoni Rovira i Trias. The Diputation of Barcelona also initiated new road layouts, such as Sarrià Avenue, Sants to Les Corts road, and Sagrera to Horta road. During this time, the port was expanded, and the first public parks, like the General's Garden, were created due to the Industrial Revolution's urban growth and environmental degradation. The walls surrounding the city were demolished after popular demand, leading to significant urban changes. The telegraph service also began in 1855, managed by the State and later incorporated into the postal service.

In summary, the 18th and 19th centuries saw Barcelona's urban development, including infrastructure improvements, the growth of its railway network, the establishment of public safety services, and the creation of public parks. These developments transformed the city and paved the way for its future expansion.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona underwent significant urban transformation after the demolition of the city walls, which had become a health hazard due to overpopulation. The walls were torn down following a popular movement led by Pedro Felipe Monlau, who published a memoir advocating for their destruction. In 1859, the City Council organized a competition for urban expansion projects, which was won by Antoni Rovira i Trias, but the Ministry of Development imposed Ildefons Cerdà's project, known as the Cerdà Plan. This plan introduced an orthogonal layout, with wide streets and an octagonal floor plan for buildings, allowing for better circulation. Cerdà's design included main avenues, large squares, and new ring roads, as well as green spaces, service areas, and various facilities. The plan aimed to improve living conditions, promote functional, recreational, and welfare aspects, and create a well-structured, organized city layout.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona experienced significant urban transformation after demolishing its city walls. The Cerdà Plan, imposed by the Ministry of Development, introduced an orthogonal layout with wide streets and octagonal building blocks for better circulation. The plan included main avenues, large squares, and new ring roads, as well as green spaces, service areas, and facilities. Cerdà's vision aimed to improve living conditions, promote functional, recreational, and welfare aspects, and create a well-structured, organized city layout.

Cerdà's design called for buildings of 16 meters in height and 10 to 20 meters in depth. The Eixample was to be divided into sectors of 20 x 20 blocks, further divided into districts and neighborhoods, each with specific facilities and public spaces. However, many of these provisions were not realized due to opposition from the City Council and real estate speculation.

Cerdà's urbanistic theory was based on hygienism, circulation, and multipurpose design. His plan was often superimposed on existing suburban layouts and had to consider various factors like highways, railroads, and canals. The naming of new streets was entrusted to Víctor Balaguer, who chose names inspired by Catalonia's history.

As real estate speculation led to the neglect of necessary improvements in the old part of Barcelona, the idea of "interior renovations" emerged. Miquel Garriga i Roca and Àngel Baixeras presented plans for modernizing the city's core, with Baixeras' project focusing on opening three major thoroughfares in the old city center. However, Garriga's project faced execution challenges, and Baixeras' plan was not realized until 1879 due to the absence of expropriation mechanisms.

In the mid-19th century, Barcelona underwent significant urban transformation, which included the introduction of the tramway for urban transport in 1872. Miquel Garriga i Roca and Àngel Baixeras presented plans to renovate the city's interior, with Baixeras' plan focusing on opening three major thoroughfares in the old city center. However, Garriga's project faced execution challenges, and Baixeras' plan was not realized until 1895 due to the absence of expropriation mechanisms. Only the first thoroughfare, Vía Laietana, was built in 1908.

During this period, street furniture grew, especially after Antoni Rovira i Trias became head of Buildings and Ornamentation of the City Council in 1871. The installation of electric lighting began in the 1880s, gradually replacing gas lighting on public roads. The first telephone communication in the whole peninsula took place in Barcelona in 1877, and the number of telephones in the city grew progressively, reaching 850,000 in 2000.

Additionally, numerous supply markets were built in the last third of the century, many of them made of iron, reflecting the architectural trends of the time.

Under the dictatorship of Primo de Rivera in 1925, the telephone service was nationalized, leading to the creation of the Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España. The number of telephones in Barcelona increased significantly from 2479 in 1897 to 850,000 in 2000. During this period, several supply markets were constructed, many of them made of iron, reflecting contemporary architectural trends. The Universal Exposition of 1888 had a substantial impact on Barcelona, driving urban development and modernization. The event, held in the Citadel Park, led to various infrastructure improvements, including the remodeling of the Salón de San Juan and the urbanization of the city's seafront. Additionally, Pere Garcia Fària initiated a project in 1891 to regulate the city's sewage system, emphasizing hygienism and establishing a visitable sewerage network.

During the dictatorship of Primo de Rivera in 1925, the telephone service was nationalized, resulting in the formation of the Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España. Barcelona's urban development and modernization were significantly influenced by the Universal Exposition of 1888, held in the Citadel Park. This event led to infrastructure improvements, including the remodeling of the Salón de San Juan and the urbanization of the city's seafront. Pere Garcia Fària initiated a sewage system regulation project in 1891, emphasizing hygienism and creating a visitable sewerage network.

Golondrinas, pleasure boats, started operating from the end of the century, offering rides in front of the Columbus statue. The city's sewage network was expanded, and streets were urbanized with tiled sidewalks and cobblestone roadways. The increase in population and industrial needs led to a larger water collection and distribution network, with a new pipeline built from Dosrius (Maresme).

During the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, new hospitals were established to serve the growing population, such as the Hospital Clínico y Provincial, Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau, and Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron. The Eixample was progressively urbanized through private initiative and the Sociedades de Fomento, followed by the Comisiones Especiales de Ensanche from 1892.

The 20th century was marked by political instability, with the end of the monarchy, the arrival of the Second Republic, the Civil War, Franco's dictatorship, and the reestablishment of the monarchy and democracy. Immigration led to a significant increase in Barcelona's population, peaking between 1970 and 1980 with 1,754,900 inhabitants. The city's political leaders, such as Francesc Cambó, Enric Prat de la Riba, and Josep Puig i Cadafalch, aimed to elevate Barcelona to the level of international cities like Paris, New York, Berlin, and Vienna.

In the early 20th century, Barcelona underwent significant expansion, annexing several neighboring towns and growing from 15.5 km² to 77.8 km². This growth led to the need for a plan to connect the city, resulting in Léon Jaussely's 1903 plan. Jaussely proposed a structural scheme with main axes, zoning of activities, and systematization of green spaces. His plan, which was partially realized, envisioned large road infrastructures, parks, rail links, public buildings, and facilities. The most notable action during this period was the opening of Via Laietana in 1908, which connected the Eixample with the sea. The city's leaders aimed to elevate Barcelona to the level of international cities, focusing on infrastructure, industrial needs, population growth, and aspects like education and green spaces.

In the early 20th century, Barcelona experienced significant growth, leading to the expansion of its infrastructure and urbanization of surrounding areas. Léon Jaussely's 1903 plan aimed to modernize the city with main axes, zoned activities, and systematized green spaces, resulting in projects like Via Laietana and the urbanization of Tibidabo's slopes, which featured single-family homes and funiculars. The Can Muntaner estate project, led by Eusebi Güell and Antoni Gaudí, aimed for a garden city concept but was unsuccessful. The port was expanded, and the city saw general electrification, giving rise to industrial growth. Public transportation expanded with tramways and buses, with the tramway network extension being particularly notable. Despite progress, some projects, like the opening of two additional roads, faced criticism and were partially realized or abandoned.

In the early 20th century, Barcelona underwent significant expansion, including the growth of public transportation. Tramway lines to nearby towns emerged in 1916, and city buses were reintroduced in 1922 by the Compañía General de Autobuses de Barcelona, which later merged with Tranvías de Barcelona. Taxis were also introduced, with 1,000 in service by 1920 and a distinct color scheme established in 1931. The Barcelona Metro began construction in 1920, with two lines operational by 1926, later merging with the bus company to form Transportes Metropolitanos de Barcelona. Additionally, public schooling and green spaces gained importance, with the latter's development proposed in a series of concentric semicircles by Nicolau Maria Rubió i Tudurí in 1926. The 1929 International Exposition in Montjuïc further urbanized the area and showcased noucentisme architecture.

The 1929 International Exposition in Montjuïc, which showcased noucentisme architecture, led to significant urban development in Barcelona. The exposition's urbanization project, along with the landscaping of Montjuïc mountain, created gardens such as Laribal, Miramar, and Greek Theater. The event also spurred the improvement of public spaces, transportation, and communication throughout the city, including the construction of the Prat Airport, the renovation of the France Station, and the elimination of level crossings. These advancements resulted in increased immigration, leading to the development of working-class neighborhoods and, unfortunately, the rise of shanty towns. Additionally, the first traffic lights were installed in 1929, with the first synchronization taking place in 1958. The Second Republic and self-government granted to Catalonia in 1930 further stimulated urban development projects to address the city's infrastructure, housing, transport, and facility needs.

The 1929 International Exposition in Montjuïc resulted in significant urban development in Barcelona, with the creation of gardens and improvements to public spaces, transportation, and communication. The arrival of the Second Republic and self-government to Catalonia in 1930 further stimulated urban development projects, such as the Regional Planning project and the Territorial Division of Catalonia. The Macià Plan, an innovative and avant-garde urban planning project, was generated during these years, proposing a functional distribution of the city with a new geometric order and the creation of different areas for various purposes. Although not implemented, the Macià Plan is considered a landmark in Barcelona's urban planning history. The Civil War halted urban development, including the installation of traffic lights, which was reactivated in the 1950s, leading to the first synchronization in 1958 and the establishment of the Traffic Control Center in 1984.

The Macià Plan, proposed in the 1930s, suggested creating 400x400m residential modules with large housing complexes and social facilities, and allocating green spaces and a recreational complex for leisure activities. Although not implemented, its innovative ideas influenced Barcelona's urban planning, particularly in the recovery of the seafront for leisure. During the Franco dictatorship (1939-1975), uncontrolled construction of cheap housing occurred, leading to urban sprawl, unplanned neighborhoods, and the use of cheap materials causing problems like aluminosis. Real estate speculation was facilitated by the 1942 Municipal Ordinances reform, allowing increased building heights in relation to street widths.

The Macià Plan's concept of large residential modules influenced Barcelona's urban planning, but was not implemented. Instead, uncontrolled housing construction and real estate speculation during the Franco dictatorship led to urban sprawl, unplanned neighborhoods, and the use of cheap materials. The growth of suburbs resulted in the integration of neighboring municipalities and the coining of the term "Great Barcelona." Real estate speculation was facilitated by the 1942 Municipal Ordinances reform, which increased building heights in relation to street widths, causing significant differences between buildings and disfiguring the urban space. The Regional Plan of 1953 aimed to integrate the city with neighboring municipalities, meet housing demand, curb real estate speculation, and improve the urban environment, but encountered difficulties in its application. The growth of population and new neighborhoods led to the construction of new markets and improvement of the city's road network.

During the Franco dictatorship, Barcelona experienced urban growth and modernization, but it was largely unplanned and driven by real estate speculation. The Macià Plan's concept of large residential modules was not implemented, and instead, suburbs expanded, integrating neighboring municipalities and creating the "Great Barcelona." The 1942 Municipal Ordinances reform allowed for taller buildings, disfiguring the urban space. The Regional Plan of 1953 aimed to improve the urban environment, housing, and transportation, but faced challenges in implementation.

Infrastructure projects, like the partial construction of three tunnels through Collserola mountain range and the expansion of the metro network, were carried out. Barcelona hosted the XXXV International Eucharistic Congress in 1952, leading to the development of the Congreso neighborhood. The 1958 Social Urgency Plan addressed the housing deficit with large social housing blocks in peripheral neighborhoods.

The Zona Franca, initially planned as a free trade zone in 1900, was eventually established in the 1960s as an industrial estate. During the "Porcioles era" (1957-1973), urban planning was marked by speculative large-scale real estate operations, causing popular discontent and urban social movements. The Municipal Housing Board developed large housing estates, such as Montbau, Southwest Besòs, and Canyelles.

During the Porcioles era (1957-1973), the Municipal Housing Board developed large housing estates, including Montbau, Southwest Besòs, and Canyelles. Although some positive urban development actions occurred, such as infrastructure improvements, speculative real estate operations caused public discontent, leading to urban social movements. Despite attempts at urban reorganization, like the Master Plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona (1966) and Plan Barcelona 2000 (1970), many projects were not realized, including a Universal Exposition in 1982 and the Plan de la Ribera (1964-1972). Under Franco's dictatorship, green space management focused on maintaining and restoring existing areas. With the end of the dictatorship and the advent of democracy, new socialist councils initiated an extensive urban reform program, culminating with the 1992 Olympic Games.

During the democratic era, new socialist councils led by Narcís Serra and Pasqual Maragall focused on urban planning and architecture as a way to distinguish Barcelona. They initiated an extensive urban reform program, culminating in the 1992 Olympic Games. This period saw a surge in public facilities, including schools, parks, gardens, roads, and civic, cultural, and sports centers. The city's urban landscape changed significantly due to strong public investment, which was facilitated by the relocation of factories and industrial complexes.

Urban planning during this time prioritized reconstruction over expansion and public initiatives over private ones. The city was viewed as a collection of distinct realities, with each public space intervention aiming to regenerate underprivileged areas and compensate for quantitative and qualitative shortcomings.

Industrial restructuring, driven by the Plan for the reindustrialization of Barcelona's center, resulted in the creation of a Zona d'Urgent Reindustrialització (Urgent Reindustrialization Zone) (ZUR). The new industrial development emphasized R&D and new technologies.

The General Metropolitan Urban Development Plan (1976), drafted by Joan Antoni Solans, aimed to curb speculation and rehabilitate the most degraded urban spaces. The Metropolitan Corporation of Barcelona was established, which included Barcelona and 26 surrounding municipalities. The plan outlined three main action lines: small-scale urban rehabilitation, urban restructuring, and morphological reorganization. However, the project was never fully implemented due to numerous lawsuits and claims, resulting in its dissolution in 1985.

From 1983 to 1989, the concept of "areas of new centrality" was developed to create a more polycentric and better-connected city. Twelve areas were identified for regeneration, and numerous city road stretches were improved with pedestrian-friendly, landscaped avenues.

During Barcelona's democratic era, urban planning prioritized regenerating underprivileged areas and improving public spaces, leading to the development of "areas of new centrality" to decongest the city center and promote the urban periphery. Twelve areas were identified, including Montjuic, Diagonal-Zona Universitària, Vall d'Hebron, and Carles I-Avinguda Icària, for regeneration and pedestrian-friendly road improvements. Sectoral plans, such as those for Ciutat Vella, Carmel, Gràcia, Sarrià, Sant Andreu, and Poblenou, were developed, and affordable housing policies were implemented. The arrival of democracy also led to the creation of new green areas, such as the Joan Miró park, Espanya Industrial park, Pegaso park, Clot park, Sant Martí park, and Estació del Nord park. The 1992 Olympic Games further transformed Barcelona, with the construction of the Olympic Ring, the Poblenou Olympic Village, new ports, beaches, and transportation axes.

The 1992 Olympic Games drove significant urban planning and transformation in Barcelona, including the regeneration of underprivileged areas and the creation of new centralities. The Olympic Village, Vall d'Hebron, and Raval neighborhoods underwent major redevelopments. The Olympic Village saw the construction of the Olympic Port, new beaches, and transportation axes, as well as facilities like the Telephone Exchange and Meteorology Center. Vall d'Hebron, planned by Eduard Bru, combined green spaces and sports facilities, hosting the Olympic Press Village. The Raval neighborhood was remodeled with a new cultural center and the construction of the Center of Contemporary Culture of Barcelona and the Museum of Contemporary Art of Barcelona.

Urban planning advancements were also made in telecommunications, with the construction of the Collserola and Montjuïc communications towers and the installation of 150 km of optical fiber cabling. Barcelona's road infrastructure was expanded, particularly through the creation of ring roads encircling the city. These developments were led by Josep Acebillo and Alfred Morales between 1989 and 1992. Additionally, green areas, parks, and gardens were developed, such as the parks of Mirador del Migdia, Poblenou, Carles I, and those designed by the firm Martorell-Bohigas-Mackay. The Old Port was remodeled for leisure purposes, and a Coastal Plan was instituted to regenerate the city's beaches and improve their condition for citizens.

The 1992 Olympic Games spurred extensive urban planning in Barcelona, including the regeneration of underprivileged areas and the creation of new centralities. The Olympic Village, Vall d'Hebron, and Raval neighborhoods were significantly redeveloped, with new facilities, sports centers, cultural centers, and transportation axes. Barcelona's road infrastructure was expanded with the creation of three ring roads and the remodeling of the Old Port. Green areas, parks, and gardens were also developed. After the Games, urban planning focused on sustainability, with an emphasis on public spaces, community facilities, and environmentally friendly transport options like bicycles. The 21st century saw the creation of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council and the 22@ district, a large-scale urban renewal project in the El Poblenou neighborhood. The 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures led to further urban changes, including the regeneration of the Poblenou neighborhood and the creation of the new Diagonal Mar neighborhood.

The 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures spurred significant urban changes in Barcelona, including the regeneration of the Poblenou and Besós areas, which were previously filled with old, disused factories. The new Diagonal Mar neighborhood was created, and the city gained new parks and leisure spaces. The urban planning of the 21st century has focused on sustainability, with an emphasis on public spaces, community facilities, and environmentally friendly transport options. The 2015 Urban Master Plan (PDU) aims to promote the urban and social transformation of the metropolitan area of Barcelona, made up of 36 municipalities and 3.5 million inhabitants, by classifying metropolitan land, establishing building regulations, defining areas for urban transformation, preserving the environment, and ensuring proper mobility. The plan's conceptual objectives are to define a metropolitan urban planning model that is ecologically sustainable, economically efficient, and socially cohesive, and to establish the methods and tools necessary to carry it out. The PDU is scheduled for approval in 2021.

The 2015 Urban Master Plan (PDU) aims to promote the urban and social transformation of the Barcelona metropolitan area, made up of 36 municipalities and 3.5 million inhabitants, by classifying land, establishing building regulations, defining areas for urban development, preserving the environment, and ensuring mobility. The PDU, which is set for approval in 2021, builds on the 1976 General Metropolitan Plan and has two main objectives: defining a sustainable, efficient, and cohesive metropolitan urban planning model and establishing the necessary methods and tools to implement it. In 2016, a pilot test of "superblocks" began in Poblenou to enhance pedestrian and bicycle traffic, public transport, and public spaces. This initiative expanded to the Eixample district in 2020, aiming to create 42 new green axes and squares by 2030. The COVID-19 pandemic led to temporary urban planning changes, such as setting aside spaces for pedestrians and terraces for bars and restaurants, some of which became permanent. The PDU and these temporary measures aim to align with the Sustainable Development Goals promoted by the United Nations.
